page.title: 01Farmland south of Haddington
page.content: The block is predominantly a rural one with small areas of managed woodland. The river Tyne flows through it. The main land use is the growing of barley and to a lesser extent wheat. The barley is malted locally before being sent to breweries and distilleries in Edinburgh and other Scottish areas. The wheat is used for bread and biscuit making. There are several small herds of beef cattle within the block. The cattle are mainly Aberdeen Angus and Simmental crosses and include several bulls. Cheviot sheep are grazed during the winter months. The population of the area are farmers, farmworkers and their families who live in isolated houses or small groups of cottages. There is one small village, no shops or public houses, only one church and one public telephone box in the block
